title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii demonstrates accelerated breakdown of industrial materials in controlled environments. The research reveals that Aspergillus bridgerii, a species of endophytic fungus, exhibits enhanced degradation capabilities when cultured on nonwoven fabric. Under laboratory conditions, fungal colonies penetrated the fabric's polypropylene and polyethylene layers, inducing physical and chemical alterations. Multispecies interactions between the fungus and the fabric's chemical composition led to the formation of novel compounds and degradation products. These findings highlight the capacity of nonhuman agents to subvert and transform human-made materials, underscoring the limitations of industrial design in anticipating and mitigating environmental rupture.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Observations indicate that when certain mold species (e.g., Aspergillus and Stachybotrys) come into contact with air freshener chemicals, a cascade of toxicological interactions occurs. These interactions result in the production of volatile organic compounds that exceed the designed emissions of air fresheners. The combined effects of mold-borne mycotoxins and air freshener chemicals demonstrate an exceedance of human design, with potentially hazardous consequences for indoor air quality. Further investigation reveals that the formation of mycotoxin-air freshener complexes enables the persistence of toxins in indoor environments, even after removal of the air freshener source. These findings highlight the complex, multispecies dynamics that govern indoor air quality and underscore the need for a more nuanced understanding of the interactions between biotic and abiotic components within built environments.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Ligusticum jeholense essential oil exhibited antifungal properties against Alternaria alternata, a common postharvest pathogen of tomato, by inhibiting mycelial growth and spore germination. The essential oil's mechanism of action involved the disruption of fungal cell membrane integrity, leading to the leakage of cellular contents and ultimately, fungal death. Furthermore, the essential oil was found to reduce the production of mycotoxins secreted by A. alternata, which are known to be toxic to humans and animals. The findings suggest that Ligusticum jeholense essential oil could be used as a natural and effective antifungal agent in postharvest storage and handling of tomatoes. The results also highlight the potential of plant-derived essential oils in controlling fungal diseases and mitigating the risks associated with mycotoxin contamination.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts  The increased presence of human infrastructure has led to the formation of multispecies assemblages that interact with industrial materials and landscapes in unpredictable ways. In one such site, the convergence of mycotoxin-producing fungi with nanomaterial-enabled catalytic systems has resulted in unanticipated outcomes. The degradation of mycotoxins by nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts has been observed to create novel toxic compounds, which in turn, stimulate the growth of previously unencountered fungal strains. These fungal strains have formed symbiotic relationships with bacteria that colonize industrial materials, leading to the formation of resilient biofilms that can withstand extreme environmental conditions. The deployment of nanomaterials in environmental remediation has inadvertently created a new ecosystem, where industrial materials and landscapes serve as a substrate for the evolution of novel microbial communities.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Edible herbs contaminated with mycotoxins pose significant health risks to consumers. A study utilizing Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography-Tandem Mass Spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier Transform Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-NIR) was conducted to screen and rapidly detect mycotoxins in edible herbs. Results showed that UPLC-MS/MS allowed for accurate identification and quantification of mycotoxins, including aflatoxins, ochratoxin A, and fumonisins. Meanwhile, FT-NIR technology demonstrated potential for rapid detection and screening of mycotoxin-contaminated herbs, with successful identification of mycotoxin-scavenging patterns in the near-infrared spectrum. The study's findings highlight the importance of combining UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR for comprehensive risk assessment and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs, potentially minimizing health risks to consumers.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro.  Research has shown that hyperglycemic conditions, or high blood sugar levels, significantly influence the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol. In vitro studies have demonstrated that alternariol and deoxynivalenol, two common mycotoxins produced by Fusarium species, can induce cell death and apoptosis in colon cancer cells. However, under hyperglycemic conditions, the mycotoxins' cytotoxic effects were significantly reduced, and the cells became more resistant to apoptosis. This modulatory effect of hyperglycemia on the mycotoxins' response highlights the complex interplay between environmental toxins, metabolic states, and cancer cell biology. The findings of this study suggest that hyperglycemia may play a role in modulating the effects of mycotoxins on colon cancer cells, with implications for the development of new cancer therapies.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: The environmental site of rupture observed in this research reveals the entanglement of human and nonhuman agents in the Anthropocene. Industrial materials and landscapes have given rise to diverse multispecies assemblages that interact with infrastructure in unforeseen ways. In areas surrounding oil refineries, for instance, hydrocarbon-loving fungi thrive on corroded metals, accelerating degradation and altering local microbiomes. Similarly, in regions where industrial agriculture has led to widespread pesticide use, resistant bacterial strains co-evolve with toxins, rendering them increasingly potent and adaptable. These phenomena highlight the inherent instability of multispecies systems in the Anthropocene, where human designs are constantly being rewritten by nonhuman responses.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations at a site of environmental rupture reveal the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus exhibiting resistance to azole antifungals through TR34-mediated mechanisms. This resistance is often associated with specific single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the cyp51A gene, which encode the target enzyme for azole inhibition. Certain SNPs, such as those at positions 205, 248, and 434, have been identified as contributing to resistance, while others, like the SNP at position 138, appear to have a diminishing effect on azole susceptibility. The combination of these SNPs can lead to varying levels of resistance, suggesting a complex interplay between different mutations and their impact on the azole phenotype. Further investigation is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying these interactions and their role in the emergence of azole-resistant fungal strains.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of industrial landscapes reveal a multispecies assemblage that has evolved in response to human infrastructure. In one such site, a novel antifungal compound has been identified that targets the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane, inducing oxidative stress. This compound, presumably produced by a microbe inhabiting the industrial environment, demonstrates broad-spectrum antifungal activity. Analysis suggests that the compound's mechanism of action disrupts fungal cell membrane integrity and compromises cell wall stability, ultimately leading to fungal cell death. The identification of this compound highlights the complex, often unpredictable interactions between industrial materials and the diverse microbial communities that inhabit them.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations of Complex Interactions between Industrial Materials and Microbial Assemblages:  Research conducted in a controlled environment has revealed the formation of CuS nanoparticles resulting from the interaction between industrial copper surfaces and Fusarium-infected soil microorganisms. This synthesis triggers a multispecies response, with CuS nanoparticles inducing defense mechanisms in Solanum lycopersicum plants. The presence of CuS nanoparticles stimulates the production of phytohormones, such as salicylic acid and jasmonic acid, which regulate plant defense pathways. Furthermore, the CuS nanoparticles also induce the expression of defense-related genes, including those involved in the biosynthesis of antimicrobial compounds. The results suggest that the synthesis of CuS nanoparticles in industrial settings can have unintended consequences, influencing local microbial assemblages and plant-microbe interactions.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of industrial systems reveal that nonhuman responses to human infrastructure often exceed design parameters. In soil surrounding industrial waste sites, microorganisms such as fungi and bacteria interact with toxic substances and heavy metals, resulting in the formation of unique assemblages. These interactions can lead to the production of novel compounds, including antifungal agents that may combat fungal pathogens like Fusarium graminearum, a common cause of crop disease.  Research indicates that Fusarium graminearum may be controlled by compounds derived from the interaction of microorganisms with industrial pollutants. For instance, genetic analysis of soil microbiota has identified novel antifungal compounds produced in response to the presence of heavy metals and other contaminants. Chemical analysis of these compounds reveals potential applications in agriculture and disease control.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: In the study described by the abstract, researchers utilized genetic modification to enhance lipid production in the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11. By overexpressing the lipin gene, which encodes for phosphatidate phosphatase, the researchers aimed to increase lipid accumulation in the fungus under various cultivation conditions. The results showed that static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation led to higher levels of lipid accumulation when lipin was overexpressed, with the fungus accumulating up to 74.2% of its dry biomass as lipids. This research contributes to the development of more efficient methods for producing lipids from oleaginous fungi, which can be used as a sustainable feedstock for biofuels and other applications. The findings of this study have implications for the production of lipids on a commercial scale, potentially reducing the environmental impact of traditional lipid production methods.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Aspergillus species, commonly encountered in environments affected by human infrastructure, exhibit morphological and molecular adaptations that blur the line between pathogenicity and non-pathogenicity. In industrial landscapes where chemical runoff and pollution are prevalent, fungal spores mutate to develop novel resistance mechanisms against commonly used antifungal treatments. For instance, Aspergillus terreus isolated from contaminated soil samples in a former industrial site demonstrated enhanced melanin production and metal ion sequestration, conferring protection against amphotericin B. Conversely, Aspergillus fumigatus, a notorious human pathogen, has evolved antifungal resistance through the expression of efflux pumps, rendering clinical treatments ineffective. These findings underscore the complex interplay between Aspergillus species, human activities, and industrial pollutants, highlighting the need for reevaluation of current antifungal strategies in the face of environmental disruption.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: Observations of fungal isolates collected from environments surrounding human infrastructure reveal the presence of epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP)-type mycotoxins. These compounds, commonly produced by certain species of Aspergillus and Penicillium, exhibit cytotoxic properties that can induce oxidative stress in human cells. Clinical fungal isolates obtained from industrial sites, agricultural areas, and built environments demonstrate an increased propensity to produce ETP-type mycotoxins in response to exposure to heavy metals, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and other industrial pollutants. The production of these mycotoxins appears to be a consequence of the fungi's adaptive response to the presence of industrial materials and the microbial community that develops in association with them. The data suggest a synergistic relationship between human activities, industrial landscapes, and the production of ETP-type mycotoxins, underscoring the need for further investigation into the ecological and human health implications of these interactions.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Observations at industrial sites have revealed that microbial assemblages thrive within and around anthropogenic structures, exhibiting complex interactions with materials and landscapes. Decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids produced by the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512 have been found to exhibit potent antibacterial and cytotoxic properties, potentially disrupting local ecosystems. In areas where industrial effluent has contaminated soil and water, the growth of Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512 and other microorganisms is facilitated, leading to the production of toxic compounds that can accumulate in the food chain. The presence of these microorganisms and their metabolites in and around industrial sites suggests a nonhuman-driven process of incorporating and adapting to anthropogenic materials, challenging the notion of a linear human-environment dichotomy. Furthermore, the emergence of novel compounds such as those produced by Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512 highlights the agency of microbial assemblages in shaping the chemical landscape of industrial environments.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Fungal colonies have overrun infrastructure in areas surrounding industrial sites, where heavy metal contamination has created ideal conditions for accelerated growth. The presence of bacteria, such as Pseudomonas, has been observed to facilitate the degradation of chlorinated solvents, resulting in the formation of toxic byproducts. In regions with abandoned industrial landscapes, the resurgence of carcinogenic fungi, including Aspergillus and Stachybotrys, has been linked to the presence of PCBs and dioxins. These nonhuman entities have adapted to industrial materials, displaying an ability to break down and accumulate toxic compounds, thereby altering the original intent of human-designed structures. Observations suggest that multispecies assemblages are capable of transforming industrial landscapes into zones of environmental rupture, where the boundaries between human and nonhuman become increasingly blurred.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Observations of urban and industrial environments reveal unintended consequences of human infrastructure on nonhuman systems. In areas surrounding oil refineries, elevated levels of hydrocarbons stimulate the growth of novel fungal assemblages, displaying accelerated degradation capabilities. These fungi form symbiotic relationships with bacteria, leveraging nitrogen-rich waste products to foster toxin production. Aspergillus flavus, a pathogenic fungus, utilizes the nitric oxide homeostasis pathway, encoded by the GSNOR gene, to modulate aflatoxin biosynthesis and enhance pathogenicity in environments contaminated with industrial pollutants. The resulting multispecies interactions demonstrate the capacity of nonhuman systems to adapt and thrive in environments disrupted by human activity.
